lead_paragraph: Some criticized the department’s decision to shield information from journalists as a step away from transparency.

byline.contributor: Al Baker and Ashley Southall contributed reporting.

headline.print_headline: Police, Citing Law, Stop Sharing Personnel Data
headline.main: New York Police Dept., Citing Law, Stops Sharing Personnel Data

snippet: Some criticized the department’s decision to shield information from journalists as a step away from transparency....
abstract: New York Police Dept has stopped sharing daily 'personnel orders,' register of news and information, including disciplinary reports, about department's thousands of officers and civilian employees, citing state’s civil-rights code classifying such information as confidential; critics challenge interpretation, saying it limits public access to information, particularly in cases where officers are accused of wrongdoing.
